item.title: Coffee and Conversation - R-Ladies St. Louis
item.description:
Chapter: R-Ladies St. Louis

When: Saturday, February 28, 2026 at 4:30 PM UTC

Where: Webster Groves Public Library

Attendees: 13 going

Join us for a morning of conversation and networking with fellow women in data. If you’re interested in data careers, looking to hire from underrepresented groups in data, or wanting to brainstorm about a project you’ve been working on, we’d love to see you. This is an in-person event and refreshments will be provided, so we appreciate your RSVP.

item.title: Programando en R con GitHub Copilot - R-Ladies Santa Rosa
item.description:
Chapter: R-Ladies Santa Rosa

When: Saturday, January 31, 2026 at 1:00 PM UTC

Where: Online event

Attendees: 7 going

R-Ladies Santa Rosa invita a una charla para descubrir cómo **GitHub Copilot puede integrarse en el trabajo diario con R.** **Yanina Bellini Saibene mostrará aplicaciones prácticas tanto en la interfaz de GitHub como en RStudio,** explorando cómo este asistente ayuda a escribir código y a probar ideas. No se requiere experiencia previa con Copilot, solo curiosidad por nuevas formas de programar y compartir en comunidad. ¡Te esperamos!

View event details
item.author: noreply@rladies.org (R-Ladies Santa Rosa)

item.title: Git & GitHub: Practical Version Control for Data Work - R-Ladies Rome
item.description:
Chapter: R-Ladies Rome

When: Thursday, January 29, 2026 at 6:00 PM UTC

Where: Online event

Attendees: 94 going

Version control is no longer optional for data analysis, research, or collaborative projects. In this session, we introduce **Git and GitHub** with a practical, workflow-driven approach. We will cover: * What Git is and why it matters for reproducibility and collaboration * Core concepts: repositories, commits, branches, and history * Using GitHub to share work, track changes, and collaborate safely * Common workflows for data scientists and analysts The session is designed for beginners and self-taught users who want a clear mental model and practical habits they can immediately apply. No prior experience with Git is required. Bring curiosity and your laptop.

View event details
item.author: noreply@rladies.org (R-Ladies Rome)

item.title: Analyse Factorielle Multiple: analyses de groupes de variables (quanti et quali) - R-Ladies Limoges
item.description:
Chapter: R-Ladies Limoges

When: Wednesday, January 28, 2026 at 11:30 AM UTC

Where: Faculté des Lettres & des Sciences Humaines

Attendees: 3 going

Nous présentons l’analyse factorielle multiple ou (AFM, Escofier & Pagès 1994) avec le package R [FactoMineR](http://factominer.free.fr/factomethods/analyse-factorielle-multiple.html) (Josse & Husson 2008). Cette approche a pour but de cibler de grandes tendances variationelles au sein d’un jeu de données comprenant plusieurs groupes de variables (ex : **groupe 1** « personnalité », **variable 1** : « timidité », **var. 2** : « résistance au stress », **var. 3** : « sociabilité » …). Les variables peuvent être qualitatives, quantitatives ou les deux. Le nombre de variables par groupe peut varier et l’importance de chaque groupe est pondérée de façon à ce qu’ils aient le même poids. Cette approche est utilisée dans les études de comportement alimentaire (Ares et al. 2010), en écologie (Poulard et Léauté 2008), sensorimétrie (Stanimirova et al. 2011), sociolinguistique (Amand 2019) ou pour analyser les résultats de questionnaires d’enquête de satisfaction (Bécue-Bertaut et al. 2008). L’AFM permet, en outre, de hiérarchiser soit les variables, soit les groupes de variables en fonction de leur influence sur la variation générale. L’AFM met également en valeur les types de corrélation présents entre les variables. Combinée à une classification hiérarchique (Husson 2010), il est possible de construire des groupes d’individus basés sur les schémas variationnels dominants dégagés par l’AFM. Des graphiques accompagnent chaque tableau de diagnostique de l’AFM (grandes tendances, co-occurrence, groupes d’individus et individus médians ou atypiques), ce qui facilite l’interprétation.

View event details
item.author: noreply@rladies.org (R-Ladies Limoges)

item.title: TidyTuesday - R-Ladies Ottawa
item.description:
Chapter: R-Ladies Ottawa

When: Tuesday, January 27, 2026 at 11:00 PM UTC

Where: Bayview Yards

Attendees: 17 going

Join R-Ladies Ottawa for a casual evening of programming on Tuesday, January 27th. We'll be participating in TidyTuesday, a weekly data visualization challenge organized by the *R for Data Science* community. **What is TidyTuesday?** Every week, a new dataset is posted online on the [TidyTuesday GitHub repo](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday), and folks from around the world create data visualizations using the dataset. It's an opportunity to put your programming skills into practice using real-world data in a way that's fun! It's also a great way for everyone to learn from each other, by sharing their visualizations and code. **What will the dataset be?** Even we don't know that (yet)! We'll have to wait until the day before the event to know what data we'll be working with. If you're interested in seeing some past datasets, take a look at the examples below, or visit the [TidyTuesday GitHub repo](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday) to see all of the datasets dating back to 2018. *Examples from past TidyTuesdays:* * [Donuts, Data, and D'oh - A Deep Dive into The Simpsons](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/main/data/2025/2025-02-04/readme.md) * [Pokemon](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/main/data/2025/2025-04-01/readme.md) * [What have we been watching on Netflix?](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/main/data/2025/2025-07-29/readme.md) **Do I have to use R?** No! You can use any programming language or visualization software that you want. In fact, Python users from around the globe participate in "TyDyTuesday" on a weekly basis. **Who is this event for?** No previous programming experience is required to participate, and we'll have experienced programmers in the room who can help you get started (or unstuck), if needed. ...But if you want to get the most out of the event, a good way to prepare is to watch the recording of the [introduction to data visualization workshop](https://rladies-ottawa.github.io/events/2024/intro_to_r.html) we hosted back in 2024. :) **What should I bring?** * Please bring a laptop so you can code along. We recommend that you have RStudio or another IDE (such as VS Code or Positron) installed ahead of time, but we can help you get one installed if needed! * Come ready to learn, share, and contribute to a safe and welcoming community! **How will this event work?** * First few minutes of the event: Introductions, and taking a look at the dataset together as a group. * Time to create a data visualization using the language or software of your choice, either on your own or with a (new) friend! Grab a free snack while you're at it :) * Last \~30 minutes of the event: Show and tell session for anyone who would like to share their creation with the group. **What else do I need to know?** This event (like all R-Ladies events) is totally FREE to attend. The event will take place at Bayview Yards, which is located just a few steps away from the Bayview O-Train station. There is also a free parking lot available for those who are driving. You can find us in the "Training Room", which is on the second floor of the Bayview Yards building. *This is an in-person event with limited space! Please only RSVP if you are able to attend in-person!* **\*\*\*Please note that the mission of R-Ladies is to increase gender diversity in the R community. This event is intended to provide a safe space for women and gender minorities. We ask for male allies to be invited by and accompanied by a woman or gender minority.\*\*\*** We’re grateful to be part of the Bayview Meetups initiative and extend our thanks to Bayview Yards for generously providing the venue space.

View event details
item.author: noreply@rladies.org (R-Ladies Ottawa)
